enum.name: Level
enum.summary: Describes how hard to understand or use a specific option or feature is.

value.name: Recommended
value.summary: This choice is easy to understand and recommended. Typically, out of multiple options, only one is the recommended one.

value.name: Easy
value.summary: This choice is easy to understand.

value.name: Escape
value.summary: This corresponds to a negative decision, such as No, Cancel

value.name: Advanced
value.summary: This choice cannot be expected to be the right choice for a basic user. It will only be offered to advanced users.

enum.name: Severity
enum.summary: The severity of a message. Do not use high severities unneccessarily as not to annoy the user.

value.name: Info
value.summary: The message is an information. Such a message usually disappears after some time or may not be shown at all.

value.name: Success
value.summary: Some action the user requested succeeded. Such a message usually disappears after some time or may not be shown at all. Examples: success message

value.name: Warning
value.summary: Some action the user requested could not be started or something else happened that the active user should known about. Examples: battery low

value.name: Error
value.summary: Some action the user requested could not be completed or something else happened that the active user should known about. Examples: service crashed

struct.name: Text
struct.summary: Holds one or more localized strings that describe the same thing with different degrees of detail.

field.name: Summary
field.summary: This should be short, very easy to understand and not use any technical terms.

field.name: Details
field.summary: A more detailed version of the message. Can be null.

field.name: Debug
field.summary: This should include all technical details about the message, specifically for power users and developers. Can be null.

struct.name: Option
struct.summary: Represents a possible answer by the user to a question posed to the user.

enum.name: Key
enum.summary: Represents a normal key (everything that is not an action key).

enum.name: KeyModifiers
enum.summary: Represents one or multiple modifier keys.

field.name: Key
field.summary: If Unknown, check the Char field.

field.name: Char
field.summary: Holds the unicode char associated with the key press. Null if no unicode char can be assigned to the key press.

enum.name: Modality
enum.summary: Governs the display style and behaviour of a UI window or panel.

value.name: StaticContent
value.summary: A panel with this modality is usually displayed as a tab in a window with static tabs and cannot be moved around.

value.name: DynamicContent
value.summary: A panel with this modality is usually displayed as a dynamic tab and can be moved around, docked to any position in the parent window. This is suitable for the documents in a multi-document interface or for the tabs in a browser.

value.name: StaticToolbox
value.summary: A panel with this modality is usually displayed as a docked side bar and cannot be moved around. On a small display, a swipe from the side may be required to reveal the panel. If multiple panels with this modality are displayed, they may share a single side bar and switching is possible through tabs.

value.name: DynamicToolbox
value.summary: This defines a behaviour that is usually equal to DynamicContent. The only difference is that such a panel is by default docked to a side instead of filling the main area.

struct.name: GridDefinition
struct.summary: Specifies the appearance of a single grid column or row. todo: maybe allow to specify a size relative to another grid definition

field.name: Tight
field.summary: If true, the actual column width or row height is calculated according to the space requirements of the cells.

field.name: Size
field.summary: The relative column width. If Tight is true, a value of 1 means that the column is just wide enough to fit the content. If Tight is false and all columns have the same Size value, all will have the same width, but still at least the content width.

field.name: Resizable
field.summary: If true, the user may be able to resize the column width or row height.

method.name: Write
method.summary:
Prints the specified text on the console starting at the current cursor position. The cursor is advanced to the location after the text. If a character is printed below the last line, the buffer is scrolled accordingly. This function shall accept \n as a new line character.
todo: differentiate between the following cases: 1. bare input/output streams (i.e. a serial communication line) 2. a simple text-based screen buffer (where we can print any char anywhere) 3. a fully controllable terminal (where we can clear the screen and scroll) case 3 can be built from case 2 or from System.Console (this works only on Windows though)

param.name: textColor
param.summary: The text color (this may be ignored by some implementations).

param.name: backgroundColor
param.summary: The background color (this may be ignored by some implementations).

method.name: Read
method.summary: Waits for a single key stroke and returns the result. Modifier keys are not recognized on their own. The pressed key is not printed to the console.

method.name: Scroll
method.summary: Scrolls the specified number of lines up or down. This may not work on some consoles.

param.name: lines
param.summary: The number of lines. Positive is down, negative is up.

property.name: WindowSize
property.summary: The size of the console in chars.

property.name: CursorPosition
property.summary: Gets or sets the current cursor position. (0, 0) denotes the top left corner of the console.

property.name: CursorVisibility
property.summary: Gets or sets the visibility of the cursor.

interface.name: Shell
interface.summary:
A shell is the environment which manages the interaction with the user. A shell may be a console, a graphical user interface, a speech based interface or anything else that allows for interaction with the user.
Actually, let's refine that: A shell is just an environment for the action, that can be used by the action to interact with the platform. If, e.g. an action is executed in a console, that doesn't mean that the console is used for all user interaction. The job of figuring out the right mode of interaction is the job of the user experience service.

method.name: PresentDialog
method.summary: Presents a message to the user and allows the user to select one out of a set of possible answers. Depending on the setting (e.g. if the user is absent or if the shell is not interactive), the shell may decide on its own. If the shell makes the decision, it shall do so according to the following rules: If the user has answered the same question previously in the same or similar context, the last selection shall be returned. If there is are recommended options, the first one shall be selected. If there is no recommended option, the first option shall be selected.

method.name: Notify
method.summary: Notifies the user about something, e.g. a success or error message. Depending on the setting and severity, the message may disappear after some time or not be shown at all.

interface.name: UI
interface.summary: Represents the most general description of a user interface. A user interface is usually graphical and 2D, but could conceptually also be presented in 3D, a console or through a speech interface.

property.name: ID
property.summary: A key that is unique with respect to the containing context (i.e. parent window or application). This is used by the shell to store and retrieve the window configuration.

property.name: Modality
property.summary: Governs the modality in which the UI is displayed

property.name: Title
property.summary: The title of the UI. This usually makes up the title and subtitle of a window or view.

property.name: Menus
property.summary: Shall provide all feature sets with a scope that spans the entire UI, or features that should always be visible. This may include things such as "Open" or "Create New".

interface.name: Menu
interface.summary: Represents a collection of features that should probably be displayed in a group.

property.name: Panels
property.summary: Represents the set of panels that should be available in the UI. Their modality defines how these behave.

property.name: Content
property.summary: Contains the UI element to display.

interface.name: UIElement
interface.summary: Base class for all UI elements.

interface.name: Frames
interface.summary: Provides a way of displaying multiple elements on top of each other.

property.name: Frames
property.summary: Specifies the frames being displayed.

interface.name: Grid
interface.summary: Arranges child elements in a matrix.

property.name: RowDefinitions
property.summary: Specifies the row definitions of the grid. If the rows exceed the available space, scrolling is enabled.

property.name: ColumnDefinitions
property.summary: Specifies the column definitions of the grid. If the columns exceed the available space, scrolling is enabled.

property.name: Content
property.summary: Holds the actual UI elements of the grid. The row and column with index 0 correspond conceptually to the first row and column in the grid. Whether this corrsponds to the top and right side, depends on the UI context.

interface.name: Button
interface.summary: Displays an element that has an on and off state. This can be a button, a checkbox, a switch or something similar. has a textbox as content but can contain any UI element.

property.name: Content
property.summary: The content inside or next to the control. This is usually a textbox.

property.name: Pressed
property.summary: The pressed-state of the control. This is set and reset by the shell when the user clicks on the button.

interface.name: Textbox
interface.summary: Displays text. The text can be selectable, editable or none.

property.name: Style
property.summary: Customizes the text appearance. If null, the context in which the text is shown defines the style.

property.name: InputOptions
property.summary: Specifies the behaviour of text input. If null, the text cannot be edited.

property.name: SelectionOptions
property.summary: Specifies the behaviour of text selection. If null, the text cannot be edited.

property.name: Content
property.summary: The graphics to be displayed

property.name: Items
property.summary: Represents the list of items that should be displayed in the list view. Depending on the context and platform, tool windows may be floating or docked to a side of the parent window.
